intro: Corydalis aurea var. parviflora, commonly known as the dwarf golden corydalis, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Asia. It is a member of the Fumariaceae family and is characterized by its delicate, spurred flowers that range in color from yellow to orange. The plant typically grows to a height of about 10-20 centimeters, with slender stems and lance-shaped leaves. It thrives in cool, moist environments and is often found in shaded woodland areas. Its ornamental value makes it a popular choice for rock gardens and woodland plantings.
